extracted_ttps.description: The threat actor used Python to create a backdoor (THINCRUST) on the FortiManager device.
Threat actor exploited a local directory traversal zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2022-41328) in FortiOS to write files to FortiGate firewall disks outside of normal bounds allowed with shell access
The threat actor used legitimate credentials to access the FortiManager device and deploy backdoors.
The threat actor exploited a path traversal vulnerability (CVE-2022-41328) in FortiGate devices to upload malicious files and execute commands.
Threat actor maintained persistent access with Super Administrator privileges within FortiGate Firewalls
Attacker used Unix Shell to execute commands
Threat actor disabled OpenSSL 1.1.0 digital signature verification of system files through targeted corruption of boot files
Attacker removed log entries containing IP address
Threat actor exploited a zero-day vulnerability in FortiOS to gain initial access to the FortiGate firewall
Attacker used obfuscated files or information
Attacker used SSH for lateral movement
The threat actor accessed and read files from the FortiGate devices using the THINCRUST backdoor.
Threat actor used social engineering to trick the user into executing the malicious script /bin/support
Threat actor used the CASTLETAP backdoor to sniff network traffic and discover open ports
Threat actor used the TABLEFLIP utility to redirect traffic and maintain command and control
Attacker modified system files to bypass digital signature verification
indicators: printf "t" | dd of=/bin/smit bs=1 count=1 conv=notrunc seek=22866 2>/dev/null

extracted_ttps.description: Attacker used non-standard ports for communication
Threat actor used ICMP port knocking to maintain persistent access to FortiGate Firewalls
The threat actor used FortiManager scripts to deploy backdoors (CASTLETAP) across FortiGate devices.
Threat actor modified the startup file /etc/init.d/localnet to execute the malicious script /bin/support
Attacker used a dead drop resolver
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker used PowerShell to execute commands
Attacker staged data locally
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Threat actor stole user credentials to maintain long-term access to victim environments
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: THINCRUST Backdoor Execution via Python on FortiManager
rules.description: Detects the execution of the THINCRUST backdoor on FortiManager devices via Python interpreter using known malicious file path and indicator in command line.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts on FortiManager that import or reference the urls.py module for valid purposes.
Authorized Python-based maintenance tools that operate within the same directory structure.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Exploitation of FortiOS CVE-2022-41328 Directory Traversal Vulnerability
rules.description: Detects potential exploitation of CVE-2022-41328, a directory traversal vulnerability in FortiOS, allowing threat actors to write files to FortiGate firewall disks outside normal bounds. This rule identifies suspicious command-line activity involving path traversal and file writing using common exploitation techniques.
falsepositives: Administrative scripts that legitimately write to system directories using shell commands
Automated configuration backup or update scripts on FortiGate devices

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Potential Screen Capture via Encoded Commands
rules.description: Detects processes associated with browsers/screenshot tools executing base64-encoded commands containing screen capture keywords
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using encoded commands for screen sharing utilities

rules.title: Unix Shell Command Execution via Suspicious Utilities
rules.description: Detects execution of iptables, grep (without -v), awk, or xargs within a Unix shell process, which may indicate malicious command execution.
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts or shell usage

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Detect OpenSSL Execution with Signature Verification Disabled
rules.description: Detects execution of OpenSSL where command line arguments disable digital signature verification, indicating possible impairment of defenses by corrupting boot files or bypassing signature checks.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of OpenSSL by developers or administrators for testing certificates where verification is intentionally disabled
Automated build or CI pipelines that use OpenSSL with '--no-verify' flags for internal signing

rules.title: Linux Log File Tampering via Echo/Sed
rules.description: Detects log file clearing/modification using echo redirection or sed deletion patterns in common log directories
falsepositives: Legitimate log rotation utilities
System administration scripts performing log maintenance

rules.title: Linux Obfuscated File Execution via klogd
rules.description: Detects execution of /bin/klogd with command-line obfuscation patterns and known malicious MD5 53a69adac914808eced2bf8155a7512d.
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration using encoding tools with klogd (rare)

falsepositives: Legitimate automation scripts using SSH

rules.title: Detection of Non‑Standard Port Usage in Process Command Lines
rules.description: Detect processes that are launched with command‑line arguments specifying ports outside the standard range (0‑1023), indicating possible use of non‑standard ports for command and control or data exfiltration.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative or testing tools (e.g., netcat, PowerShell scripts) that specify high ports for debugging or internal services
Custom applications that use high‑number ports for legitimate communication

rules.title: ICMP Port Knocking to FortiGate Firewall
rules.description: Detects potential ICMP port knocking behavior targeting FortiGate firewalls by identifying multiple ICMP echo requests from the same source in a short time window.
falsepositives: Network monitoring tools sending periodic ICMP pings
Administrative diagnostics using ping sweeps or continuous ping
Automated backup or failover systems testing connectivity

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Scheduled Task/Job Persistence via Init Script Modification
rules.description: Detects potential persistence via scheduled task/job creation by modifying init scripts or systemd units
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration activities, such as updating init scripts or systemd units

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Dead Drop Resolver – Detect Encoded Payloads and Screenshot Commands
rules.description: Detects potential dead drop resolver activity by identifying base64‑encoded command lines containing screen‑capture indicators, known indicator strings, and legitimate screenshot tools or browsers invoked with screen‑capture flags.

detection.condition: selection_base64 or selection_indicator1 or selection_indicator2 or selection_browser or selection_screenshot

falsepositives: Legitimate use of PowerShell with -EncodedCommand for automation scripts.
Browsers started with --screenshot or similar debugging flags.
System administrators using Snipping Tool or third‑party screenshot utilities.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detect PowerShell Execution with Encoded Commands
rules.description: Detects execution of PowerShell with encoded commands (e.g., -enc or -EncodedCommand) which is indicative of malicious activity.

detection.condition: selection_powershell and (selection_enc_flag or selection_enc_flag_alt or selection_base64)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use PowerShell with -enc for automation
Security or monitoring tools that invoke PowerShell with encoded commands for internal purposes
Windows Update or system maintenance tasks that may run PowerShell with encoded arguments

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Local Data Staging to Web Server Log Files
rules.description: Detects processes that write data to web server log files (/var/log/django.log or /var/log/apache2/*) while also using encoding commands or generic file manipulation tools, indicative of local data staging.

detection.condition: (selection_log_files or selection_log_apache) and (selection_encoding or selection_encoding_flag or selection_decode or selection_tools)

falsepositives: Legitimate log rotation or backup scripts that copy log files to other locations
System administration tasks that archive or compress log files using cat, cp, mv, or tee
Scheduled maintenance jobs that encode logs for transmission (e.g., for remote monitoring)

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Credential Dumping and Suspicious Encoding Detection
rules.description: Detects execution of known credential dumping tools, PowerShell base64 encoded commands, browsers used to capture credentials, and screenshot utilities that may be leveraged for credential theft.

detection.condition: selection_lsass or selection_mimikatz or selection_procdump or selection_ps_enc or selection_browser or selection_screen

falsepositives: Legitimate use of procdump.exe by administrators for troubleshooting
System administrators running PowerShell scripts with -EncodedCommand for automation
Users taking screenshots with snippingtool.exe or similar utilities for documentation
Browsers being launched for normal web browsing

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Archive Collected Data – Detect Archiving of Screen Capture Files
rules.description: Detects processes that create archive files containing screen‑capture data, including detection of Base64‑encoded payloads referencing screen‑capture keywords. Expands coverage to common archiving utilities and browsers.

detection.condition: (selection_archive and (selection_capture or selection_capture_b64)) or (selection_browser and (selection_capture or selection_capture_b64))

falsepositives: Legitimate users manually compressing screenshots or screen‑capture files.
Backup or maintenance scripts that archive image directories.
Browsers downloading legitimate archives that contain the literal string "screen-capture" in filenames or URLs.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detect PowerShell Encoded Commands Targeting Screen Capture
rules.description: Detects PowerShell execution with Base64‑encoded payloads containing the keyword "screen-capture" and also monitors native screenshot tools and browsers launching such PowerShell commands.

detection.condition: selection_powershell or selection_powershell_plain or selection_screenshot_tool or selection_browser

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use PowerShell with -EncodedCommand for automation.
Users manually taking screenshots with built‑in tools (Snipping Tool, Snip & Sketch, Greenshot).
Browsers launching PowerShell for legitimate extensions or developer tools.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process – Detect Screenshot Capture via Encoded Payloads
rules.description: Detects creation or modification of system processes used for screen capture, including direct screenshot tools, browsers spawning screenshot utilities, and PowerShell commands with base64‑encoded payloads containing screen‑capture keywords.

detection.condition: selection_screenshot_process or selection_browser_child or selection_powershell_enc or selection_plain_keyword

falsepositives: Legitimate use of Snipping Tool or third‑party screenshot utilities by users.
Administrators running PowerShell scripts with -enc for benign automation.
Browsers launching built‑in screenshot extensions or developer tools.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

falsepositives: Legitimate use of screenshot tools or browsers

attacks.description: Clears the Security log, potentially removing indicators of malicious activity.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Security log will be cleared, removing all log entries.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-EventLog -LogName Security -EntryType Error | Where-Object {$_.Message -like '*192.168.1.100*'} | ForEach-Object {Remove-EventLog -LogName Security -EntryType Error -InstanceID $_.InstanceID -Force}"
attacks.description: Removes specific error log entries from the Security log containing the IP address 192.168.1.100 using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Log entries containing the specified IP address will be removed from the Security log.

attacks.command: for /f "tokens=*" %a in ('wevtutil qe Security ^| findstr /i 192.168.1.100') do wevtutil cl "Security"
attacks.description: Queries the Security log for entries containing the IP address 192.168.1.100 and then clears the log if such entries are found, using a batch command.
attacks.expected_behavior: If log entries containing the specified IP address are found, the entire Security log will be cleared.

attacks.description: Remove log entries containing the IP address 192.168.1.100 from the auth.log file using sed.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command removes lines containing '192.168.1.100' from /var/log/auth.log.

attacks.description: Clear the auth.log file by overwriting it with an empty string, effectively removing all log entries.
attacks.expected_behavior: The auth.log file will be emptied.

attacks.description: Recursively find all log files in /var/log and remove lines containing '192.168.1.100' using sed.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lines with '192.168.1.100' are removed from all files in /var/log.

attacks.description: Advanced SSH command simulating lateral movement with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a connection, elevates privileges to root, and writes a file to the root directory, simulating advanced lateral movement techniques

attacks.expected_behavior: Listens for incoming connections on a non-standard port

attacks.description: Establishes a telnet connection to a non-standard port
attacks.expected_behavior: Demonstrates communication over a non-standard port using telnet

attacks.description: Listen on non-standard port 8080 using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat will listen on port 8080, and any incoming connection can be handled by the attacker.

attacks.description: Connect to a remote server on non-standard port 8081 using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat will establish a connection to the specified server on port 8081, allowing for potential command and control communication.

attacks.description: Listen on non-standard port 8082 and execute /bin/bash upon connection using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: Upon an incoming connection, netcat will execute /bin/bash, providing a shell to the attacker. This command poses a higher risk due to the execution of a shell.

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate a ping request, which could be part of a protocol tunneling technique, redirecting output to a log file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command pings the localhost, simulating network activity, and logs a message to a file in the temp directory, indicating a potential tunnel establishment without causing harm.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to create a TCPClient object, simulating a connection attempt which could be used in protocol tunneling, then immediately closes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command attempts to establish a TCP connection to a local endpoint and then closes it, simulating a brief, potentially tunneling-related network interaction.

attacks.description: Advanced command utilizing certutil to download a benign file from a URL, simulating data transfer through a potentially tunneled protocol, and then displays the file's content.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file using certutil, which could be used in a protocol tunneling scenario for data exfiltration or infiltration, and then displays the file's content, demonstrating potential data transfer capabilities.

attacks.description: Basic ICMP packet sending to simulate initial contact
attacks.expected_behavior: Sending a single ICMP packet to the specified IP address

attacks.command: for i in {1..5}; do ping -c 1 192.168.1.1; sleep 1; done
attacks.description: Intermediate command to simulate a sequence of ICMP packets for port knocking
attacks.expected_behavior: Sending a sequence of ICMP packets with a delay between each packet

attacks.description: Advanced command to simulate a complex sequence of ICMP packets for persistent access
attacks.expected_behavior: Sending a complex sequence of ICMP packets with varying counts and delays to mimic advanced port knocking

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task to execute a command that writes to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task named 'Test Task' is created and executed daily, writing 'Hello' to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task to execute a PowerShell command that displays a message box
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task named 'Test Task' is created and executed daily, displaying a message box with 'Hello'

attacks.description: Basic example: Creates a new startup file /etc/init.d/localnet with a bash script that executes /bin/support, makes it executable, and updates the runlevels to include the new script.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will execute /bin/support at startup.

attacks.description: Intermediate example: Backs up the original /etc/init.d/localnet file, then modifies it to execute /bin/support, and makes it executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will execute /bin/support at startup, and the original file is backed up.

attacks.description: Advanced example: Uses crontab to schedule the execution of /bin/support at system reboot, without modifying existing startup files.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will execute /bin/support at the next reboot.

attacks.description: Basic command to download a benign string using certutil.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the benign string to the temp directory without causing system instability.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to download an encoded benign string, decode it, and save the decoded string to a new file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the encoded benign string, decode it, and save the decoded string to a new file without causing system instability.

attacks.description: Advanced command to download an encoded benign string, decode it using findstr, and save the decoded string to a new file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the encoded benign string, decode it using findstr, and save the decoded string to a new file without causing system instability.

attacks.description: Resolve the domain name example.com using the dig command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will resolve the domain name example.com and print the IP address

attacks.description: Simulate command and control communication using the curl command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will simulate command and control communication by transferring data from the web server example.com

attacks.description: Resolve the domain name example.com and simulate command and control communication using the dig and curl commands
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will resolve the domain name example.com, simulate command and control communication by transferring data from the web server, and print the output to /dev/null

attacks.description: Basic example of using PowerShell to get a list of running processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes on the system

attacks.description: Intermediate example of using PowerShell to make a web request
attacks.expected_behavior: Makes a web request to the specified URL and gets the response

attacks.description: Advanced example of using PowerShell to compress a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses the specified file into a ZIP archive

attacks.description: Basic command to write the current date to a file in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'date.txt' will be created in the temporary directory with the current date

attacks.description: Intermediate command to write the list of running processes to a file in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'processes.txt' will be created in the temporary directory with the list of running processes

attacks.description: Advanced command to compress a file in the temporary directory and overwrite any existing archive
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip archive named 'archive.zip' will be created in the temporary directory with the 'date.txt' file, overwriting any existing archive

attacks.description: Create a directory in the temp folder and a file within it to stage data locally
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory named 'staged_data' will be created in the temp folder, containing a file named 'test.txt' with the content 'Test data'

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to create an archive of a file, demonstrating intermediate data staging
attacks.expected_behavior: An archive named 'staged_data.zip' will be created in the temp folder, containing the 'test.txt' file

attacks.description: Use certutil to decode a Base64-encoded string and save it as a file, exemplifying advanced data staging
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'decoded.txt' will be created in the 'staged_data' directory, containing the decoded content of the Base64-encoded string in 'base64.txt'

attacks.description: Creates a new file in the /tmp directory with test data, demonstrating local data staging.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named staged_data.txt will be created in the /tmp directory containing the test data.

attacks.description: Creates a compressed archive in the /tmp directory containing the /etc/hosts file, demonstrating local data staging using compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new compressed archive file named staged_data.tar.gz will be created in the /tmp directory, containing the /etc/hosts file.

attacks.description: List all user accounts on the system
attacks.expected_behavior: Output a list of user accounts on the system

attacks.description: List saved credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Output a list of saved credentials

attacks.description: Dump the contents of the SAM database
attacks.expected_behavior: Output the contents of the SAM database, including hashed user passwords

attacks.description: Retrieve user information, potentially including credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user information, including encrypted passwords if accessible.

attacks.description: Search for password entries in system configuration files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files containing the string 'password', potentially revealing credential storage locations.

attacks.description: Combine password and shadow files for potential cracking, demonstrating credential dumping.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named 'cracked.txt' containing combined user and password information, ready for cracking attempts.

attacks.description: Basic archive creation using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named archive.zip in %TEMP% containing test.txt

attacks.description: Intermediate archive creation using .NET assembly
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named archive2.zip in %TEMP% containing all files in the collect directory

attacks.description: Advanced archive creation with directory setup
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory named data in %TEMP%, then creates an archive named advanced_archive.zip containing all files in the data directory

attacks.description: Creates a compressed archive of collected data using tar.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed archive named collected_data.tar.gz is created in the current directory.

attacks.description: Creates an archive of collected data using zip.
attacks.expected_behavior: An archive named collected_data.zip is created in the current directory.

attacks.description: Creates an archive of collected data using 7z.
attacks.expected_behavior: An archive named collected_data.7z is created in the current directory.

attacks.description: Basic command to execute a PowerShell script that writes the current date to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named date.txt in the temp directory containing the current date.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using the call operator (&) to execute a script block that writes 'Hello World' to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named hello.txt in the temp directory containing 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Advanced command using EncodedCommand to execute an encoded string that prints 'Hello World'.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Hello World' to the console.

attacks.description: Basic command to write the current date to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named date.txt will be created in the temp directory with the current date

attacks.description: Intermediate command to compress the date.txt file into a zip archive
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named date.zip will be created in the temp directory containing the date.txt file

attacks.description: Advanced command to remove the date.txt and date.zip files from the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The date.txt and date.zip files will be removed from the temp directory

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe /c echo 'Test Service' > %TEMP%\test.txt"
attacks.description: Create a new service named TestService that executes a cmd.exe command to write a test string to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named TestService is created, and upon starting, it writes 'Test Service' to a file named test.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Modify the TestService to start automatically on system boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService is configured to start automatically when the system boots.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to start the TestService, demonstrating an alternative method of interacting with system processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService is started using PowerShell, and the test.txt file should be created or updated in the temp directory indicating the service has run.

attacks.description: Modify the cron table to create or modify a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the cron table in the default editor, allowing the user to add, modify, or delete cron jobs.

attacks.description: Start a system service using systemd
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts the 'myservice' system service if it exists and is configured properly.

attacks.description: Modify system startup scripts to create or modify a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: Updates the system startup scripts to include 'myscript' in the default runlevels.

attacks.description: Basic: Setting up a netcat listener to receive data from a C2 channel and save it to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat listener starts, waiting for incoming connections on port 8080 and saves received data to exfil.txt.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Using bash to create a test file, then using netcat to send the file over a C2 channel to a remote server.
attacks.expected_behavior: A test file is created in the temporary directory, and its contents are sent over the network to a remote server using netcat.

attacks.description: Advanced: Using bash and tar to compress a sensitive file, then exfiltrating it over a C2 channel using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The /etc/passwd file is compressed into a tarball, which is then sent over the network to a remote server using netcat, simulating exfiltration of sensitive data.
